#TBT ‚Äì a young woman uses a PLATO terminal as part of her studies, circa 1974-75. 

The creation of PLATO (Programmed Logic for Automated Teaching Operations), a computer-based learning environment developed by physicists and engineers at the University of Illinois, represented the first use of a computer for pedagogy, the first time-shared education system, and the home of the first on-line community. 

Learn more about PLATO at: https://www.uiaa.org/illinois/news/blog/index.asp?id=163.

Aerospace Engineering at The University of Illinois alumna develops website for young adults with cancer

At the age of 24 and just two months after losing her mother to a brain cancer, Mallory Casperson again had to face the 'C' word, as she was diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma in February of 2011. She had completed her bachelor's degree in aerospace engineering at the University of Illinois and was coming off a stressful time where she had to balance her second year of graduate school in AE while serving as a part-time caregiver for her mother in suburban St. Louis. 

Read more of Mallory's story at: http://engineering.illinois.edu/news/article/8670#sthash.5qaeFgG0.dpuf

The Hallene Gateway located near the Alice Campbell Alumni Center.

The pillars forming this archway were originally located on University Hall, the first building on what later became the Quadrangle. University Hall was demolished in 1938, but the pillars escaped destruction and were discovered lying hidden in weeds at nearby Allerton Park. The plaza is the focal point of the east entry to the campus.

A lot has changed since brothers Brandon and Jason Dirden moved to New York in 2006 seeking theater careers. Back then, Brandon says, auditioning felt like "trying to sneak in the back door on a covert mission," since they didn't have the stamp of a famous theater school on their resumes.

But with these two University of Illinois alumni now starring in Broadway shows ‚Äì Brandon as Martin Luther King Jr. in All The Way Broadway with Bryan Cranston, and Jason opposite Denzel Washington in A Raisin in the Sun ‚Äì the temperature in audition rooms has gotten noticeably warmer.

"The Alma Mater is far more than a bronze statue. Truly it represents Illinois in a special way and she really is considered a member of the Illinois family. It's one of the first landmarks prospective students learn about. Pictures with Alma Mater usher freshman into a new, transformative world. Its presence in photographs from Mom's Weekend, Dad's Weekend, graduation and even weddings is a stamp of Illinois pride. And, of course, graduation photos with Alma have become one of our most visible and most-revered annual traditions. It will be good to have her home again."
~ Phyllis Wise, Chancellor of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

A special thank you to alumni and friends who have given to the Chancellor's Fund. The Chancellor's Fund is an unrestricted fund provides flexible resources that help contribute to creating a campus environment where students and faculty can stretch the boundaries of discovery and explore complex issues in a manner that honors our land grant tradition and propels us toward the future.

#TBT - Alma Mater makes her return to campus next week from The Conservation of Sculpture & Objects Studio in Forest Park, Illinois. However, this wasn't Alma's first time in the Chicago area.

Circa 1928, workers stand by a headless Alma Mater as they prepare to move one of Lorado Taft's best known and most beloved works from Chicago to Champaign. Taft, an early alumnus, was a prolific sculptor, educator and writer who gained much fame for his works of art and his efforts to bring culture to the rapidly industrializing state of Illinois. This image of the statue, from the University Archives' Lorado Taft Papers, depicts a partially completed Labor on the left and Learning on the right and the empty chair where Alma Mater herself would ultimately reside.

Before Alma returns on April 9, let's take a minute to get to know her sculptor, Lorado Taft.

Lorado Zadok Taft (1860-1936) - Zadok‚Ä¶who knew?
     ‚Ä¢ Graduate of the Illinois Industrial University (which later became the University of Illinois) and the Ecole de Beau Arts in Paris.
     ‚Ä¢ Author of "The History of American Sculpture" and was called "the Dean of Chicago sculptors." 
     ‚Ä¢ Taft had an encyclopedic knowledge of classical sculpture and even collected plaster casts of classical works. He hoped to one day open a sculpture museum in which Americans could view replicas of great classical sculpture from around the world. Upon his death, many of these came to the University of Illinois.

Alumnus Astronaut Mike Hopkins, a U.S. astronaut who recently spent 166 days orbiting Earth in the International Space Station, will deliver the Commencement address at the University of Illinois on Saturday, May 17.

Hopkins, who earned an aerospace engineering degree at Illinois in 1991, graduated from NASA's astronaut candidate training program in 2011. In March he touched down on Earth after orbiting the planet more than 2,500 times and participating in two space walks

Read more about Mike at http://news.illinois.edu/news/14/0401commencement.html.

Last year more than 1,500 volunteers participated in more than 20 volunteer projects across #Chambana for the Community Campus Day of Service. This year, members of the local community and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign faculty, staff, & students will join forces once again to kick off National Volunteer Week 2014, which will take place from April 6-12.

Our primary project, The Food Packaging Project, involves packaging 147,000 meals - one thousand for every year of public engagement since #ILLINOIS was chartered - for local foodbanks to be distributed to needy families in Champaign-Urbana.

Learn how you can participate by visiting https://cuvolunteer.org/DayOfService. #CCDOS14

#TBT - Did you know, as part of the plan to move Alma Mater, several concept photographs were created before her eventual placement in front of Altgeld Hall? This concept was to place the statue in front of the Illini Union. ca. 1961

#TBT - Alma Mater was cast in 1929 by the American Art Bronze Foundry with materials paid for by donations by the Alumni Fund and the classes of 1923-1929, and with time donated by the sculptor Lorado Taft.

For 33 years, the statue's location was behind Foellinger Auditorium, but the Alumni Association moved her next to Altgeld Hall on August 22, 1962.

Alma Mater is scheduled to return to campus on Wednesday, April 9, 2014.

15 more days until she returns to campus!

In August 2012, the Alma Mater was removed from her granite pedestal and transported to The Conservation of Sculpture & Objects Studio in Forest Park, Illinois for conservation. Due to years of deterioration, it was determined parts of the sculpture needed to be disassembled and all corroded bolts and fasteners removed and replaced.

Watch this video from University of Illinois Facilities & Services to learn more about the restoration process and what it took to bring Alma Mater back to campus https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QuILawF3iHM&list=PL267C0BFDAB145133.
link_name: University of Illinois Facilities & Services - Conservation of the Alma Mater

Send your own greeting to 'thy happy children of the future'

Students, faculty and staff may send an electronic greeting to the Illinois family of the future via a time capsule to be placed inside the Alma Mater sculpture when it returns to campus.

In the spirit of the inscription on the sculpture's base, "To thy happy children of the future those of the past send greetings," the campus is soliciting messages, which may be submitted by filling out at form located at http://go.illinois.edu/almagreetings. Submissions will be considered for inclusion on a data file to be placed in the time capsule, which may not be opened for more than 100 years. The deadline for submissions is midnight, March 30.

*A NetId is required.

Brevity is a must ‚Äì greetings are limited to 750 characters

Welcome home! Former Fighting Illini Football player & Astronaut Mike Hopkins returned to Earth last night.

In a recent interview, Hopkins was asked which planet in the solar system he would most like to visit. He promptly said "Earth."

"Being away from Earth, this is an absolutely incredible experience and it's something I'll never forget," he said. "But I'm getting ready to come home, and I'm looking forward to it.

"You see the views of Earth up here, and it is truly stunning, and it's something that never gets old. But at the same time, I'm really looking forward to feeling the Earth between my toes, feeling a breeze, maybe even standing out in a rain storm. Earth is truly incredible, and I think that's where I'd like to go."

Read more at http://www.cbsnews.com/news/astronauts-return-from-space-station-could-be-delayed-by-weather/

Engineering students creating energy everyone can afford

In Asia and Africa, nearly 1.5 billion people live in "off the grid" villages with an acute electricity shortage. Often their only source of light is kerosene lamps, which expose families to toxic fumes and risk of home fires.
Engineering at Illinois students, Patrick Walsh, Anish Thakkar and Mayank Sekhsaria launched Greenlight Planet to change that.

The Chicago-based company produces solar-powered lamps geared toward these rural communities. Since launching in 2009, the startup has sold 1.8 million lamps, which cost between $11 and $40, the equivalent of about two weeks wages in those communities. One million were sold in the last ten months alone. 

Read more at: http://money.cnn.com/2014/03/06/smallbusiness/greenlight-planet-solar-lamps/ via CNNMoney.com

Learn about Greenlight Planet at: http://greenlightplanet.com/about.

Watch the NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams tonight for a feature on #ILLINOISalumna Tatyana McFadden as she prepares for the Sochi Paralympic Games. And tune in to the Today Showtomorrow morning during the 7:00 a.m. Central Time hour, where they'll feature Tatyana too!

Engineering at Illinois professor John Rogers and his team of researchers have created an external membrane using a 3-D printer than can keep a heart beating virtually forever. It is about 10-15 years away from being made available to humans, but the revolutionary device might one day help to prevent heart attacks.
link_name: Membrane that can keep heart pumping forever, prevent heart attacks

University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Engineering at Illinois and the National Center for Supercomputing Applications - NCSA will play a key role in the recently announced Digital Lab for Manufacturing. Based in Chicago, the lab is a public-private partnership that will be funded by a $70 million U.S. Department of Defense grant and $250 million from industry, academic, government and community partners. The goal of the lab is to significantly reduce development and deployment costs, while creating billions of dollars in value for the industrial marketplace ‚Äî spurring long-term U.S. economic growth and job creation.

William King, the Abel Bliss Professor, Mechanical Science and Engineering at UIUC, will serve as the Chief Technology Officer for the Digital Lab.

Congratulations to former Illinois women's track and field thrower and sprinter Aja L Evans on winning the bronze medal in the women's bobsled at the Sochi 2014 Winter Games! Evans and pilot Jamie Greubel, manning the USA-2 sled, placed third with an overall time of 3:51.61, just behind fellow Americans Elana Meyers and Lauryn Williams, who took home the silver with a time of 3:50.71. It's the first time two U.S. sleds have medaled in women's bobsledding.
 
"You go into the competition setting goals for yourself, and the ultimate goal is to win gold," Evans said after winning her first Olympic medal. "But you go in with nothing, so to come out with a bronze, you've reached a goal, you've achieved a lot. I'm just as excited as if I've won gold."
  
Evans, a five-time All-American and three-time Big Ten Conference shot put champion at Illinois from 2007-10, decided to make the transition to bobsledding in March of 2012. Since then, the Chicago, Ill., native has won two-straight National Push Championship titles, a silver medal at the 2013 World Cup, a gold medal in a World Cup bobsled race held in Park City, Utah, and now a bronze medal at the Olympics.

Engineering at Illinois faculty member J. Gary Eden has been elected to the National Academy of Engineering. One of the highest professional honors an engineer can earn, Eden joins 2,250 members and 214 foreign associates in the elite group.

Eden, a 1976 #ILLINOIS graduate (Ph.D. in electrical engineering), serves as the Gilmore Family Professor of ECE Illinois. A class of ultraviolet lasers that Eden developed are used industrially in semiconductor manufacturing and clinically for eye surgeries.

status_message:
"Following the events of this week that raised the need for a campus discussion on civil discourse and respectful debate, I was asked to submit an op-ed to Inside Higher Education. This piece ran today and I want to share it with the campus community here as well.

"I have greatly appreciated the outpouring of public and private support from students, faculty, staff and alumni this week. But, at this point, I don't want to talk any more about a small number of ill-thought postings or bad behavior of a handful of individuals.

"What is really most important to me is that we, as a community, move beyond the personal aspects here of a single incident and focus our conversations and efforts on addressing the larger issues that have been raised. This is a chance for us to talk about how we go about ensuring our campus environment is one that encourages diverse opinion and fair debate and is a place where great ideas flourish."

To read Chancellor Wise's response in Inside Higher Ed, visit  http://www.insidehighered.com/views/2014/01/30/chancellor-u-illinois-responds-twitter-incident

Jenny, a tiger at the Exotic Feline Rescue Center in Center Point, Indiana, had always been active and social. She loved climbing trees. Splashing in her water tub was her favorite thing to do. But in the fall of 2012, her keepers noticed something odd. Instead of playing, Jenny was just laying down, unable to move from the neck down. She was taken to the University of Illinois Veterinary Teaching Hospital and diagnosed with a rare spinal condition.

After receiving treatment and medication, Jenny started acting like herself again. And she just keeps improving. Today, she can walk around and once again enjoy her water tub."
http://www.exoticfelinerescuecenter.org/f/EFRC_dec12_newsletter%5B1%5D.pdf

To learn more about the Exotic Feline Rescue Center, visit http://www.exoticfelinerescuecenter.org/home.html.

#ILLINOIS Student Exhibition at Figure One Gallery
Students from the College of Fine + Applied Arts at Illinois spent a semester planning, marketing, and producing the Upside Down, Left to Right exhibition that is currently on display at Figure One Gallery in downtown Champaign. It's a (first of its kind at Illinois) educational partnership between Krannert Art Museum and the School of Art + Design, intended to provide a 360 degree view of the art industry and exhibition practice.  

Check out some of the photos from the exhibition: https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=597535796978492&set=a.597534603645278.1073741828.105871762811567&type=1&theater 

The show will run from December 6, 2013 through January 25, 2013. For more information, visit their Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/seefigureone.

Dial-A-Carol celebrates its 53rd season at #ILLINOIS. Dial-A-Carol begins Thursday, December 12 at 12:01 a.m. and runs through 11:59 p.m. on December 18, 2013. To request a holiday tune, call (217) 332-1882.

Dial-A-Carol is a student-run holiday program at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Each year the students of Snyder Hall UIUC host the holiday program. Dial-A-Carol was started in December 1960 by Betty Gordon, an area office secretary, and the residents of Snyder Hall who wanted to spread some holiday cheer around campus.

The program runs 24 hours a day for seven days and is held each year during finals week of the first semester. In 2012, the program logged more than 4,000 calls from all over the world.

Here's a peek at some of our carolers in action last year: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t3m4MOW-jmI#t=157

Learn more about Dial-A-Carol at http://www.housing.illinois.edu/Current/Halls/Snyder/My%20Community%20Life/Dial-A-Carol.aspx or find them on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/DialACarol?ref=stream
Playing in the snow is more fun than studying for finals, especially when your company is as cute as the pups from Illini Service Dogs!

A new device developed at the #ILLINOIS intends to make diagnosing #AIDS easier and more accessible for people in developing countries. The instrument would eliminate the need for expensive equipment and highly trained staff, resources that are not available in many areas where the #HIV epidemic is most severe, say the researchers, who were led by Rashid Bashir, a professor of electrical and computer engineering at ECE Illinois http://www.voanews.com/content/new-test-aims-to-make-aids-diagnosis-easier/1804413.html

"In times of stress, people often seek solace through shopping," says ILLINOIS College of Business Professor Aric Rindfleisch. "The idea here is that we need some form of a cultural-based coping mechanism, because the research suggests that there is actually a short-term fix with retail therapy. Soon after purchasing something, there is a reduction of anxiety. But it doesn't last very long. It's fleeting. Materialists seek that as one of their coping mechanisms. And Black Friday and the holiday shopping season play into that."

Read more about his research at http://news.illinois.edu/news/13/1125materialism_AricRindfleisch.html
link_name: Research: Materialism makes bad events even worse | News Bureau | University of Illinois

Four University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign faculty members have been named Fellows of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, including:
‚Ä¢ Stephen A. Boppart, a professor of electrical and computer engineering, of bioengineering and of medicine
‚Ä¢ Susan Hammes-Schiffer, a Swanlund professor of Chemistry
‚Ä¢ Kanti Jain, a professor of electrical and computer engineering
‚Ä¢ William P. King, an Abel Bliss professor of mechanical science and engineering

"This year's AAAS fellows demonstrate that Illinois is at the forefront of research and innovation," said Phyllis M. Wise, the chancellor of the #ILLINOIS campus. "Their outstanding scholarship has revolutionized technologies from medical imaging to microchips and added to our fundamental understanding of chemistry and materials. These four faculty members embody the spirit of Illinois research, which seeks to advance science while shaping society."

Read more about these impressive faculty members and their achievement http://news.illinois.edu/news/13/1125AAAS_fellows_Boppart_Hammes-Schiffer_Jain_King.html

status_message:
John A. Rogers, a pioneer in flexible, stretchable electronics at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, has been given a 2013 American Ingenuity Award by Smithsonian Magazine. One award is granted in each of nine categories. Rogers is the 2013 honoree in the physical sciences, thanks to the invention of ultra-thin silicon electronics that dissolve in the body or the environment, ushering in a new era of biodegradable medical implants and environmentally friendly electronic devices. #ILLINOISinnovation

A professor at Materials Science and Engineering at the University of Illinois and the director of the Frederick Seitz Materials Research Laboratory, Rogers is a pioneer of flexible, stretchable electronics. He combines soft, stretchable materials with micro-and nanoscale electronic components to create classes of devices with a wide range of practical applications.

Story and photo courtesy University of Illinois News Bureau

Smithsonian Magazine: http://www.smithsonianmag.com/ideas-innovations/Electronics-That-Can-Melt-in-Your-Body-Could-Change-the-World-of-Medicine-231149031.html
link_name: John A. Rogers wins American Ingenuity Award from Smithsonian Magazine

How does Warren Buffett define integrity? He values the ability of a CEO to say "no." When Berkshire Hathaway purchased #ILLINOISalumna Doris Christopher's The Pampered Chef, he was impressed by her ability to say "no" to immediate runaway growth, instead opting to spend a year consolidating the business and finding their focus prior to taking on new people or customers.

In the end, Doris' patience paid off with over $700M in sales following the Berkshire Hathaway acquisition.

Ground was broken for the Armory Building on the #ILLINOIS campus‚Äîwhich was conceived as a location for housing cadet military training‚Äîon September 18, 1912. The building, designed by Illinois state architect William Carbys Zimmerman, was officially dedicated on November 1, 1914, reportedly with 15,000 people in attendance. When construction was finished, the building was considered the largest structure in the world without a center support. The 98-foot-high ceiling suspended over 80,000 square feet of floor space‚Äîincluding the track in the center of the building‚Äîis supported by three-hinged arches weighing 36 tons each

Today, the Armory Building has many functions. It houses the offices of several University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign departments and units, including the ACDIS program and three military science/Reserve Officer Training Corps programs (Army ROTC, Air Force ROTC, Marine Corps and Navy ROTC). Numerous academic courses are held each semester in the Armory's classrooms. And the track is used by the Illinois track team for training and intercollegiate competitions; by the #ROTC cadets and Police Training Institute for drills; and by University faculty, staff, and students for their daily exercise

The Rare Book and Manuscript Library at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign Main Library has acquired the extensive literary manuscripts and archives of Gwendolyn E. Brooks (1917-2000), Illinois Poet Laureate and the first African American writer to win the Pulitzer Prize.

"Not only was Gwendolyn Brooks one of the indisputably great American poets of the 20th century, but she was the second recipient of the lifetime appointment as Poet Laureate of Illinois, following Carl Sandburg who was the first," said Professor Emeritus of English Laurence Lieberman. "I can't think of any other poetry acquisition that would honor the University of Illinois Library more."

Read more about this unique and exciting acquisition at http://www.library.illinois.edu/news/featured/brooks.html.

Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at the University of Illinois Professor and Department Head, Paul J.A. Kenis, has been named the William G. and Janet H. Lycan Professor in the School of Chemical Sciences at #ILLINOIS!

Did you know that WILL-FM (then known as WIUC) signed on in 1941 with the first FM license granted to a university? In the early days, FM was so new that WILL-FM had an audience made up of the 15 to 20 people had access to FM receivers! #ILLINOIS

Their AM station went on the air in 1922, 91 years ago!

#ILLINOIS is one of 22 universities (out of over 800 evaluated) on The Princeton Review Green Honor Roll for 2014!

Many criteria were used to evaluate schools including waste practices, sources of dining hall food, methods of transportation and student groups. #ILLINOIS achieved a perfect score for environmental sustainability. #sustainableILLINOIS #GreenHonorRoll

http://www.dailyillini.com/news/campus/article_50613162-2b00-11e3-b882-001a4bcf6878.html?mode=image&photo=0

Researchers from the University of Pittsburgh's Swanson School of Engineering, Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign  are proposing to advance #3Dprinting one step ‚Äì or rather, one dimension ‚Äì further.

Thanks to an $855,000 grant from the U.S. Army Research Office, the team hopes to develop 4-D materials, which can exhibit behavior that changes over time. The #ILLINOIS team member, Ralph G. Nuzzo, the G.L. Clark Professor of Chemistry and a professor of materials science and engineering, is a synthetic chemist who has created novel stimuli-responsive materials. 

Read more about this research at http://www.rdmag.com/news/2013/10/grant-opens-new-dimension-printing-4-d #4Dprinting

University of Illinois School of Music professor Heinrich Taube has developed a computer application that could change the way music theory is taught. His app, #Harmonia, allows teachers to create assignments that students can complete online. Then, the app can play the resulting harmonies and grade the results and provide feedback for the student.

Playing StarCraft can boost problem solving and creative thinking, according to a new study by researchers at Queen Mary, University of London and University College London. Researchers found that those who engaged in the real-time military strategy game improved their "cognitive flexibility," or the ability to adjust their thinking to meet different situations.

Arthur Kramer, psychology professor at the #UniversityofIllinois, said while skills practiced in the game can transfer to closely related tasks, it isn't clear those same skills could be applied more broadly.

Read more at http://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2013/08/25/starcraft-gameplay-boosts-mental-flexibility-says-study/?mod=wsj_streaming_stream
link_name: 'StarCraft' Gameplay Boosts Mental Flexibility, Says Study

status_message:
The colorful secret of a 1,600-year-old Roman chalice at the British Museum is the key to a super¬≠sensitive new technology that might help diagnose human disease or pinpoint biohazards at security checkpoints.

The ancient nanotech works something like this: When hit with light, electrons belonging to the metal flecks vibrate in ways that alter the color depending on the observer's position. Gang Logan Liu, an engineer at the #UniversityofIllinois, who has long focused on using #nanotechnology to diagnose disease, and his colleagues realized that this effect offered untapped potential. "The Romans knew how to make and use nanoparticles for beautiful art," Liu says. "We wanted to see if this could have scientific applications."

Read the full Smithsonian article at  http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history-archaeology/This-1600-Year-Old-Goblet-Shows-that-the-Romans-Were-Nanotechnology-Pioneers-220563661.html

The #UniversityofIllinois will attempt to break The Guinness Book of World Records this Friday, August 23 at Memorial Stadium #Salsa2013 - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uU0AW7xtkXI&hd=1

Starting early Friday morning, staff from University Housing will begin creating what they hope will be the world's largest serving of salsa.

The current record of 5,868 pounds was prepared by Asociaci√≥n de Productores del Tomates de Los Palacios (Spain). The goal for the #UofI is 7,500 pounds.

The preparation of 7,000 pounds of tomatoes, 600 pounds of onions, 20 pounds of jalape√±o peppers, 375 bunches of cilantro, and 70 gallons of lime juice will begin at 5 a.m. The completed salsa will be assembled in front of students in Memorial Stadium directly following New Student Convocation.

The salsa will feature local produce, including vegetables and herbs from the on-campus Sustainable Student Farm @ The University of Illinois Champaign-Urbana.

A representative from Guinness World Records will be on hand to certify the results. If the salsa is a record-breaker, Guinness will present a certificate to the University on the spot. After certification by Guinness, the salsa will be served at dinner on Saturday in University Housing's dining halls. 

In 2011, the University of Illinois created the World's Largest Smoothie, and in 2012 the University of Illinois broke the record for the greatest number of people simultaneously husking corn.

Pucker up - the Eternal Flame gets a makeover.
After some work this summer, the Eternal Flame is ready to go. The pillar between Lincoln Hall at U of I and the English Building is known as the Eternal Flame, a gift from the graduating class of 1912. Formerly an ever-burning oil lamp, with the saying "a lovers kiss will bring eternal bliss" kissing your sweetheart under the flame meant your love would last forever. Now, the electric light tends to flicker on and off, so students have changed the myth: lovers who kiss underneath the flame are doomed to an on and off relationship. Kiss your special someone here and find out!

Congratulations to Nick Holonyak, professor of Engineering at Illinois, for making the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s "Seven Over 70" list of distinguished researchers - http://www.technologyreview.com/fromtheeditor/518386/seven-over-70/

Nick Holonyak invented the first practical light-emitting diode in 1962 when he was a researcher at General Electric (GE), but his innovations are not limited to the replacement for the incandescent lightbulb. He also created the electronic element of the light dimmer switch and the laser diode, which is used in DVD players and cell phones. ¬≠Holonyak, 84, is still a full-time researcher at the #UniversityofIllinois, where he works on quantum-dot lasers, which could be used for a variety of novel display and medical technologies.

Afraid there may be peanuts or other allergens hiding in that cookie? Researchers at the #UniversityofIllinois have transformed a smartphone into a handheld biosensor to run on-the-spot tests for food safety and more.

The handheld biosensor was developed by researchers at the Illinois. A series of lenses and filters in the cradle mirror those found in larger, more expensive laboratory devices. Together, the cradle and app transform a smartphone into a tool that can detect toxins and bacteria, spot water contamination and identify allergens in food.

Kenny Long, a graduate researcher at Illinois, says the team was able to make the smartphone even smarter with modifications to the cellphone camera.

http://www.usatoday.com/videos/news/2013/08/01/2607563/ #foodallergy #peanutallergy #innovation

Trio of Department of #Geology alumni from the 1960s and 70s turn out to be rock stars in their field.

This year, three alumni from the University of Illinois College of LAS Department of Geology whose time on campus overlapped some 40-plus years ago have become president or president-elect of three separate, major earth science organizations with tens of thousands of members, all at the same time.

Namely, the American Geosciences Institute (AGI), American Geophysical Union (AGU), and Geological Society of America (GSA), are headed or will soon be led by Sharon Mosher (BS '73, PhD '78, geology), Margaret Leinen (BS '69, geology), and Suzanne Mahlburg Kay (BS '69, MS '72, geology), respectively.

Learn more about these successful alumni in the latest issue of LAS News http://www.las.illinois.edu/alumni/magazine/articles/2013/geology/

status_message:
What are the most influential software programs ever? Two programs developed by #Illinois alumni make the list!

Should the The Library of Congress be compiling a list of the most influential software of all time, just as it does annually for the National Film Registry and the National Recording Registry? This idea was raised at a recent meeting the Library sponsored on the long-term preservation of computer software for its cultural and historical significance. How to even begin? Restrict it to applications only, no operating systems? Home computers only? What about industrial and enterprise software? What about the software in your car or on a 777? What about software that comes to you nowadays as a service, like YouTube and Twitter? What about mobile apps?

#8 - IBM Lotus Notes, created by ILLINOIS alumni Raymond "Ray" Ozzie '79. Lotus was social media before its time, this client-server package included chat, blogging, micro-blogging, and forums as well as email, calendars, to-do lists, and lots more that we'd nowadays recognize as lifehacking. Not the sexiest pick for this list perhaps, but we couldn't imagine computers without all the things Lotus Notes did.

# 9 - #Mosaic was transitional software, the stepping stone between the text-only Lynx , which was how the World-Wide Web was originally conceived and accessed, and #NetscapeNavigator, which would dominate the browser market in the Web's early public years. But between them came Mosaic, the software famously written by a ILLINOIS undergraduate Marc Andreessen '94. Mosaic was the first graphical Web browser. Suddenly all the links were blue, suddenly every home page had a GIF cat.

See the complete list of The Top 10 Most Influential Software Programs Ever http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2013/07/30/_10_most_influential_software_programs_of_all_time_from_sabre_to_minecraft.html
link_name: The 10 Most Influential Software Programs of All Time

We can't wait to meet Grainger, the youngest member of Illini Service Dogs.

Founded in 2010, the Illini Service Dog Program is a Registered Student Organization at the University of Illinois.

Students are provided the opportunity to foster and train a #servicedog for a person with a disability. The students take the dogs to classes, sporting events, and on buses. Don't lose your head! But if you do, make sure you can regrow it. 

The mystery of why some animals can regenerate body parts while others cannot has long puzzled scientists, but three new studies have brought the issue to a head. 

"The idea that interfering with a single gene could overcome the blockage of head regeneration was a big surprise," said Phillip Newmark, a developmental biologist at the University of Illinois and leader of one of the other studies.

Knocking out a single gene can switch on a worm's ability to regenerate parts of its body, even enabling it to grow a new head. The fact that such a simple manipulation can restore healing abilities provides new insight into how the stem cells involved in this process are marshalled in animals.

Read more about this study at http://www.nature.com/news/how-to-regrow-your-head-1.13443 or http://news.yahoo.com/getting-head-worms-regenerate-lost-tissue-170954363.html

What do you do with your old cellphone? Is it sitting in a drawer? Research being conducted by John Rogers, professor of materials science and engineering, could change the way we discard obsolete, electronic devices.

Researchers at the #Illinois are designing materials that can dissolve in water. If incorporated into consumer products, the technology could help reduce the amount of toxic electronic waste in landfills.

"You don't need your cellphone to last for 25 or 50 years," says John Rogers. "You don't want to keep it that long anyway."

Watch this Associated Press video of John explaining how this new technology works http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/07/24/self-destructing-electronics-are-on-the-horizon/

The University of Illinois is proud to be recognized by Forbes in their Top 25 Best Public Colleges of 2013. #Illinois received a public rank of  #10 and an overall rank of #53. To see the full list of top schools, visit http://www.forbes.com/pictures/eidm45fhmi/university-of-illinois-urbana-champaign-4/


Forbes ranks undergraduate institutions by focusing on educational outcomes, not reputations. Rankings are based on five general categories: post graduate success, which evaluates alumni pay and prominence; student satisfaction, which includes professor evaluations and freshman to sophomore year retention rates; debt, which penalizes schools for high student debt loads and default rates; four-year graduation rates; and competitive awards.

Andreas C. Cangellaris, the head of ECE Illinois, has been chosen to be the next dean of Engineering at Illinois.

Cangellaris is broadly recognized for his research in applied and computational electromagnetics and its applications to the signal integrity of integrated electronic circuits and systems. His research has produced several design methods and computer tools that are used widely in the microelectronics industry. He has written or co-written more than 250 papers. He is affiliated with the Beckman Institute for Advanced Science & Technology and with the Coordinated Science Laboratory at Illinois.

Two University of Illinois alumni have been awarded the 2013 The World Food Prize, the foremost international award recognizing the achievements of individuals who have advanced human development by improving the quality, quantity or availability of food in the world.

Biotechnology scientists Mary-Dell Chilton, who received a Ph.D. in Chemistry from Illinois, and Robert T. Fraley, who received his Ph.D. in Microbiology/Biochemistry from Illinois, will share the honor and the $250,000 cash prize with the third winner, Marc Van Montagu of Belgium.

Illinois Hosts the 2013 National Concrete Canoe Competition

The National Concrete Canoe Competition makes its return to the place it first began: the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. More than 20 teams of college students who have designed and built concrete canoes will gather at Illinois June 20-22 to showcase the finished results of their nine-month projects. The three-day event, most of which is open to the public, will culminate in concrete canoe races on Homer Lake in nearby Homer, Illinois on Saturday, June 22.

The American Society of Civil Engineers, which organizes the intercollegiate concrete canoe competitions, will be tweeting throughout the event. Follow #concretecanoe to keep up with the latest information.
 
Civil and Environmental Engineering (CEE) at the University of Illinois 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/ceeatillinois
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/ceeatillinois
Website: http://cee.illinois.edu/concretecanoe2013

Engineering at Illinois
Twitter: https://twitter.com/EngineeringAtIL.

The University of Illinois Solar Decathlon team heads to China for a competition in early August. A total of 22 teams from 13 countries have entered the contest. Several teams have international partners, including Illinois, which also competed in the U.S. Solar Decathlon in 2007, 2009 and 2011.

The Illinois team will collaborate with students from Peking University. University of Illinois professor Xinlei Wang, faculty adviser to the group felt the collaboration was "a great opportunity" for students, providing a unique educational and cultural experience and enhancing their future careers.

To learn more about the competition, visit http://solardecathlon.illinois.edu or check out this article from the The News-Gazette 
http://www.news-gazette.com/news/local/2013-06-13/ui-solar-decathlon-team-taking-home-away-game.html.

Join Big Ten alumni in the Twin Cities while giving back to the community.

Big Ten Community Service Day is set for Saturday, July 13 from 9-11 a.m. Multi-club groups are being organized to support Feed My Starving Children (FSMC) at both their Coon Rapids and Chanhassen facilities. Additional organizations and/or locations may be added where there is interest. Friends and family members at least 5 years of age are welcome at FMSC.

To volunteer:
1. Sign-up at http://volunteer.fmsc.org
2. Choose the location of your preference - Coon Rapids or Chanhassen
3. Look for our shift date and time of Sat. July 13, 9-11 a.m.
4. Select to "Join an Existing Group" and search for "Big Ten Alumni Clubs"

For more information, call (317) 224-7950, email lubinski3nm@yahoo.com or visit http://www.tcilliniclub.org/article.html?aid=223.

status_message: Due to lightning in the area, outdoor augmented reality activity is suspended until tomorrow. Graduating students, head over to the Union for some Alma photo booth fun!

For those who can't come to see me in person. Download the app at http://go.illinois.edu/iosalma. Launch the app and aim it at the screen. Move your iPhone or iPad to view the image from different angles, from the left, the right, above and below to see me. I won't be 13 feet tall as I appear at the pedestal - I'll be much smaller.

Hi All: We're sorry the technology for this isn't working out as well as we'd hoped. We didn't have quite enough time to work out the bugs. Please know that we had the best of intentions and our team does amazing work. This feature was never meant to replace Alma. It is cool, because you can walk around the sculpture and see her new look in 3D. The rendering on an iPhone isn't able to capture the detail that the image shows. 

We have created several other Alma options that I hope you'll try. Thursday and Friday (10a - 4p), you can also go to the north lounge of the Union and get a photo booth picture with Classic Alma. Friday, Saturday and Sunday (weather permitting), we'll have six-foot tall plaster Almas at Beckman, one the Quad, at the Alice Campbell Alunni Center, at Art & Design and at the Assembly Hall. The 1867 Society will have strolling Almas around campus who will pose for pix with you, and we'll have a green screen at GradFest Sunday from 11a-2p with a very realistic background featuring classic Alma. Happy Commencement!
You have to see "me" in person.
The first augmented reality Alma photos are up. Check out the photo stream on Flickr.

Almost ready for our (augmented reality) close-up! Graduates and guests may have their picture taken with virtual me beginning at 10:00 am this morning. Huge thanks to the volunteers who will be there to take photos and answer questions.

Thank you for all of your votes in #IlliniMadness!

We started in mid-March with 64 of the greatest Illinois Innovations in our #IlliniMadness bracket. After weeks of close match-ups and thousands of votes, you have selected the transistor as the winner! The Transistor was co-invented by John Bardeen who joined the Illinois faculty in 1951. In addition to the transistor, Bardeen also co-developed the BCS Theory of Superconductivity, which made it to our round of 16!

Bardeen was named by Life Magazine as one of the 100 most influential people of the 20th century. He is also the only person to win two Nobel Prizes in Physics (1956 and 1972).

Also, a very special thank you to Mike VanBlaricum, B.S. '72, M.S. '73, Ph.D. '76 for his contributions to this project.

I-L-L!

In sticking with the Throwback Thursday theme: check out these photo-essays that travel through the evolving decades of higher education at Illinois.

#ThrowbackThursday! Alumna Ruth Anderson, 90, of Springfield, Ill., shared this 1948 UI class photo of her, film critic Gene Shalit, Playboy founder Hugh Hefner, and graduate playwriting class instructor Samson Raphaelson (a screenwriter and playwright who authored Alfred Hitchcock's "Suspicion," "Heaven Can Wait," and "The Shop Around the Corner.") Anderson is in the second row, third from the right, standing next to Hefner behind two women in the front row. Hefner is wearing a sweater over a collared shirt, first row, second from the right. Shalit is in the fourth row, first from the left, wearing a bow tie and glasses.

status_message: More pictures of my happy children from Quad Day.

The rain held off for Quad Day which made it wonderful for students! The 1867 Society shared this picture. Do you have photos to share from Quad day? I encourage new students to find an organization and get involved!
Good Morning, my children and welcome to the 2012-13 academic year. Let the classes begin!
It's Quad Day!

World corn-husking record set by my newest children today! 3,463 simultaneously husked corn. The sweet corn, all 4.18 tons of it, was sourced from Borzynski Farms in Easton, Ill. Supersweet corn was invented at the University of Illinois by professor John Laughnan in the 1960s.  A representative from Guinness World Records was on hand to certify the results, and Guinness presented a certificate to the University on the spot.
While I'm gone I've been dreaming of all the places I would like to visit. One of my bright children put my dreams in Facebook:
I'm told students are filling into Assembly Hall for convocation!

We are sorry to hear the passing of Dan Perrino (BME '48, MS '49, music education), a professor and administrator at U of I from 1960-1988. He received the Chancellor's Medallion in 1990 for his outstanding contributions to the University. He helped launch several cultural diversity programs, including the Black Chorus, La Casa Cultural Latina, Quad Day and the African American Cultural Program.

status_message: They're putting my seatbelts on.
I found out what was on the piece of paper. It was a note from 1981, when Art Department Professor Robert Youngman led efforts to repair me. His left a note thanking all those who worked on project.
The crane is off!
I"ve landed on the truck!
Here I am as I was being lifted. I overheard someone say better pictures are to come - and what they found inside me!
Don't worry! I'll be back for graduation!
Safely off - waiting for my taxi to the Chicago suburbs - a flatbed truck.
Here's Library preservationist Jennifer Teper with the paper.
I'm now off my base - and guess what - they found something inside my base - a piece of paper with something on it!
One last Friday night watching over Green and Wright. Don't worry - I'll be back before graduation in May!

status_message: Here's a short documentary from BTN about Professor Thomas K. Cureton. Cureton, who taught at the University of Illinois from 1941 to 1969, is known as the father of physical fitness. He lectured around the world and wrote more than 50 books encouraging people to lead a healthier life. He was also a champion swimmer who once held 14 world records. Thanks to Cureton, the study of physical fitness is now an accepted science.

status_message: Time for your U of I history break! Do you know which features of campus are actually gifts made by students, alumni, and friends? Find out (and learn the background stories!) through this great photo album compiled by the University of Illinois 1867 Society. Every gift makes a difference!

Alumni from the ILLINOIS College of Business' Honors Program have raised nearly $30,000 for Honors scholarships. Out of the roughly 150 alumni, close to 100 made a gift during the last year and a half. Illini know the importance of giving back!

Imagine a world where your brain is stimulated with electromagnetic impulses to reproduce the sensation of spiritual experiences. That's the reality in Professor Alex Shakar's highly praised novel, Luminarium. Hear a reading by Shakar in this brief podcast from U of I's Creative Writing Program. Shakar is followed by Professor Philip Graham, who reads from his memoir, Braided Worlds, co-authored with Alma Gottlieb.

Support local wildlife and the veterinary students who care for them at the University of Illinois College of Veterinary Medicine's annual Doodle for Wildlife auction! Proceeds benefit the Wildlife Medical Clinic at Illinois. Some celebrities who donated doodles include Margaret Atwood, Billy Idol, Bill Maher, Martin Sheen, and Loretta Switt‚Äîview their drawings online. Today is the last day to register.

status_message: Did you know...that we have a hotel right inside the Illini Union? status_message: There's always something going on at the Illini Union, our featured unit this week. Follow the Union on Facebook and Twitter (http://twitter.com/Illini_Union) to get updates on events, discounts, and more from this community center.

status_message: 'Tis the season for Dial-A-Carol, a tradition going on 51 years at U of I! Anyone from anywhere can call and request a holiday tune to be played over the phone. Or send a request to a friend in the Champaign-Urbana area (217 area code). You can call now through December 15 at (217) 332-1882. To volunteer, email dialacarol2011@gmail.com.

They are designing a Web and mobile application to replace the i-Clicker. Congratulations to architecture alumna Jeanne Gang for winning a 2011 MacArthur Fellowship! Gang is the founder and principal of Studio Gang Architects, the first female-led firm to commission a skyscraper in Chicago. Her imaginative design of the Aqua Tower was named the 2009 Emporis Skyscraper of the Year.

Wildlife myth buster, Myth 2: Should I rescue a baby bunny with its eyes open? WMC says: BUSTED! DON'T DO IT unless the bunny is hurt or in danger. They have a better chance on their own than with humans.

Wow! 1425. That's how many animals the Wildlife Medical Clinic at Illinois treated last year. And that included over 100 different species. 

The Wildlife Medical Clinic accepts ill, injured or orphaned wildlife (except for skunks and bats) 24/7. The animals are triaged and assigned to a team of 8-10 volunteers (generally veterinary students) who are responsible for treating the patient.

status_message:
It takes a lot to feed the UI campus! In a year, Univ Housing students consume 145,000 lbs of bananas. They drink 32,000 gall of milk. They consume 875 gall of kimchee. They consume 14,000 lbs of bacon. And -- grab your dipping sauce -- Univ Dining Services serves 51,000 lbs of chicken fingers in a year (that's 25.5 tons!) 

It's all good! Remember the huge cereal selection? Remember the amazing salad bars?

Now that everyone has returned to campus, they've got to eat! So this week, University Dining Services - and the 24,000 meals they serve every day - is center stage. Follow the University Housing Facebook page for news about Dining Services as well: www.facebook.com/illinoishousing.

@NCSA: Last week, MIT Technology Review covered the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope and NCSA's role in the project. Scanning the entire night sky every three days, it will collect 20 terabytes of image data every day. And that data's headed straight for NCSA.

status_message:
This Old Hall, Episode 2: The Cyclorama. (October 2010)
In this month's episode of This Old Hall, we say goodbye to a unique feature of the Lincoln Hall Theater: the cyclorama. A rarity even in its heyday, the massive steel and plaster structure no longer serves the needs of stage productions nor lectures. 
Produced by the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences Office of Communications and Marketing.
Follow the Lincoln Hall Project at http://www.lincolnhall.illlinois.edu.
Become a Fan at http://www.facebook.com/lincolnhall.illinois

In this first episode of This Old Hall, see the progress made over the summer in renovating Lincoln Hall. Crews have gutted most of the upper floors and removed or protected historical features prior to their restoration. Work has begun on the exterior.
link_name: This Old Hall: Demolition, Demolition, Demolition

status_message: Professor Yi Lu discusses his research in the field of biosensors. Lu highlights his recent work in creating biosensors that use DNA for the detection of toxins such as lead and drugs like cocaine. Lu and his lab members Yu Xiang and Zidong Wang demonstrate how they use gold nanoparticles, DNA dipsticks, a portable fluorometer, and DNA fluorescence to quickly and easily detect the presence of dangerous metals, drugs, and diseases. Lu is a faculty member at the Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology and in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
link_name: Biosensors: Professor Yi Lu (DNA toxin detection)

status_message: The University Library announces the acquisition of its 12-millionth volume---a children's book! http://ow.ly/2OTFQ
ACES' UI Extension serves up some real fun for fall on these websites: http://ow.ly/2OSI4

Professor John Rogers discusses his research in the field of biosensors. Rogers illustrates his work in creating ultra-thin and flexible biological monitoring devices to help doctors better diagnose and treat patients suffering from heart arrhythmias and brain disorders. Rogers is a faculty member at the Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology and in the Department of Materials Science & Engineering at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
link_name: Biosensors with John Rogers (Brain and Heart Biosensors)

status_message: The ARC is not your average gym. It is one of the country's largest on-campus rec centers. It has two pools, four gymnasiums, 12 racquetball courts, 3 squash courts, a climbing wall, an indoor track, seven multi-purpose rooms, an auditorium, a cycling room, instructional kitchen, personal training room, a cafe, and 34,000 square feet of strength and conditioning space. See more in the "ARC Experience" video.

Creepy Crawlers: May Berenbaum, head of the department of entomology at Illinois, talks about bedbugs in an op-ed piece in the New York Times (http://ow.ly/2n2OE) and about mosquitoes in the Pittsburgh Tribune Review (http://ow.ly/2n7Le).
link_name: Op-Ed Contributor - This Bedbug's Life - NYTimes.com

status_message: The Ice Arena is approximately 78 years old ‚Äì built around 1932 or '33.  It has always been an Ice Arena except during WWII, when it was used to house transitioning GIs.  The department of athletics ran it for some time in the 1970s, but Campus Rec has managed it since late '70s, early '80s.
What's one of the cool things about Illinois? We have a public Ice Arena! Here's a video of a typical public skating session, free to students!
This week, we'll be featuring Campus Recreation at Illinois. If you love the ARC, CRCE, the Ice Arena, Freer Pool, or intramural activities, you'll want to "like" Campus Rec's Facebook page.

Seattle-Tacoma International Airport on Thursday showed off its first-in-the-nation bird tracking system, which features real-time, mobile displays of bird activity on and around the airport. The airport in Washington has been testing the system in conjunction with the University of Illinois Center for Excellence in Airport Technology since 2007. The system uses Accipiter Radar to provide geographic displays of bird activity on Google Earth maps. http://ceatasmp.cee.illinois.edu/
link_name: Sea-Tac Airport touts real-time, mobile bird tracking
